hints.content:
The area is the number of $1 \times 1$ squares the shape covers.

 Let's count the number of squares covered in each shape to find which shape has an area of $11$ square centimeters.

[[☃ image 1]]

This shape has an area of $12$ square centimeters, not $11$ square centimeters.

options.alt:
A shape with 14 sides made up of 12 squares drawn inside a grid. The length of each side is as follows, starting from the top in a clockwise pattern, 2 squares to the right, 3 squares down, 2 squares to the right, 3 squares down, 2 squares to the left, 1 square up, 1 square to the right, 1 square up, 3 squares to the left, 2 squares up, 1 square to the left, 1 square up, 1 square to the left, 1 square up.

The squares inside the shape are counted from 1 to 12. !

hints.content:
[[☃ image 1]]


This shape has an area of $12$ square centimeters, not $11$ square centimeters.

options.alt:
A shape with 4 sides made up of 12 squares drawn inside a grid. The length of each side is as follows, starting from the top in a clockwise pattern, 3 squares to the right, 4 squares down, 3 squares left, 4 squares up.

The squares inside the shape are counted from 1 to 12. !

hints.content:
[[☃ image 1]]

This shape has an area of $11$ square centimeters.

options.alt:
A shape with 8 sides made up of 11 squares drawn inside a grid. The length of each side is as follows, starting from the top in a clockwise pattern, 1 square to the right, 1 square down, 1 square to the right, 2 squares down, 1 square to the right, 2 squares down, 3 squares to the left, 5 squares up.

The squares inside the shape are counted from 1 to 11. !

question.content:
**Which shape below has an area of $11$ square centimeters?**
[[☃ image 1]]

 is $1$ square centimeter.

[[☃ radio 1]]

options.alt: A square is equal to 1 square centimeter. !
